conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the principles of mechanics and kinematics in an electric field. The electron is injected into the electric field, and its velocity changes due to the electric force. The key is to calculate the change in velocity and then use the kinetic energy formula to find the kinetic energy at point C.

The figure shows two parallel metal plates carrying opposite charges, forming a uniform electric field. An electron is injected into the field along the central line perpendicular to the field direction with an initial velocity \( v_0 = 4 \times 10^6 \, \text{m/s} \) from point O. The electron exits the field at point C, forming a \( 30^\circ \) angle with the direction of \( v_0 \).

Identify the initial and final velocities of the electron. The electron is initially moving with a velocity \( v_0 = 4 \times 10^6 \, \text{m/s} \) at an angle of \( 30^\circ \) with the direction of \( v_0 \).
Calculate the change in velocity. The change in velocity \( \Delta v \) is given by: \( \Delta v = v_0 \sin(30^\circ) \).
Substitute the values to find \( \Delta v \): \( \Delta v = 4 \times 10^6 \times 0.5 = 2 \times 10^6 \, \text{m/s} \).
Use the formula for kinetic energy: \( KE = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 \), where \( m \) is the mass of the electron, and \( v \) is the final velocity.
Substitute the values into the kinetic energy formula: \( KE = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.91 \times 10^{-30} \times (2 \times 10^6)^2 \).
The kinetic energy of the electron at point C is \( 3.64 \times 10^6 \, \text{J} \).
